dialogue_metadata.inferred_vibe: Informative and conversational, discussing business negotiation strategies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Forty-five percent of success just from setting goals? That seems like an awfully high number to pin on just one step.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Forty-five percent of success just from setting goals? That seems like an awfully high number to pin on just one step.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Effectively identifying your goals and objectives is seemingly a simple step but many experts suggest it accounts for 50% of your success.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it's not just any goal-setting—it's about considering your whole environment, like cultural perceptions and life factors, not just profits. Advisors really emphasize that holistic view.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it's not just any goal-setting-it's about considering your whole environment, like cultural perceptions and life factors, not just profits. Advisors really emphasize that holistic view.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These are imperative, but equally vital are your business and life environment as well as the cultural perceptions and expectations of the people around you.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But writing down five goals, assessing short and long-term pressure… isn't that just common sense?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But writing down five goals, assessing short and long-term pressure... isn't that just common sense?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Therefore after writing your goals (at least four), you should assess them both from the short- and long-term perspective and a level of pressure you are ready to use on the negotiation table by asking a question about the forthcoming negotiations:

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It might seem obvious, but people skip it! And then they don't ask key questions, like whether it's a one-time deal or the start of a long collaboration.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It might seem obvious, but people skip it! And then they don't ask key questions, like whether it's a one-time deal or the start of a long collaboration.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Is this a one-time engagement or the beginning of the long road of a collaboration process, which will grow in value over time?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but what about information gathering? You can't negotiate in a vacuum.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but what about information gathering? You can't negotiate in a vacuum.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! That's where tools like the 5W1H method come in—who, what, when, where, why, how. And modern tech, um, makes it easier with databanks and social platforms.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! That's where tools like the 5W1H method come in-who, what, when, where, why, how. And modern tech, um, makes it easier with databanks and social platforms.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thus, it is important to prepare well by collecting and analyzing information using a classic MBA formula for business background research and problem solving: 5W or 5W1H (who, what, when, where, why and how). Modern Information and Communication Technologies (ICTs) provide great tools for information gathering including general business data in databanks and information about counterparts on LinkedIn, Facebook, etc.).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Social media? Like stalking someone on LinkedIn before a meeting?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Social media? Like stalking someone on LinkedIn before a meeting?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Hah, more like researching counterparts professionally. It fuels your strategy. And then there's SWOT analysis—doing one for yourself and one for the other side.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hah, more like researching counterparts professionally. It fuels your strategy. And then there's S W O T analysis-doing one for yourself and one for the other side.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is especially useful if you run one SWOT assessing your own position, and run the second SWOT for understanding the strengths and weaknesses of the other side of the table.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: SWOT's been around forever though. Is it really that useful for high-stakes talks?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: S W O T's been around forever though. Is it really that useful for high-stakes talks?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Even if it's quick on paper, it helps you spot weaknesses and strengths on both ends. Experts say it prevents desperate decisions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Even if it's quick on paper, it helps you spot weaknesses and strengths on both ends. Experts say it prevents desperate decisions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Experts even suggest developing an acceptable walk-away alternative in order not to get so desperate that you sign an abysmal deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, but what about during the actual negotiation? All prep falls apart if you can't execute.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, but what about during the actual negotiation? All prep falls apart if you can't execute.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's where tactics and confidence come in. You need a walk-away alternative, pre-meeting questions—at least ten—to avoid regrets later.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's where tactics and confidence come in. You need a walk-away alternative, pre-meeting questions-at least ten-to avoid regrets later.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Experts even suggest developing an acceptable walk-away alternative in order not to get so desperate that you sign an abysmal deal. One step is to quickly run through a set of pre-meeting questions (at least 10) and possible options, especially taking into consideration the motivation of an individual or head of a team in the forthcoming meeting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Regrets like "I forgot to ask this!"?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Regrets like I forgot to ask this!?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: How often we do hear avoidable regrets expressed by our colleagues and other negotiators I forgot to ask this question! or I forgot to clarify this issue or option!

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. And it helps you identify red herrings—things that cost you little but might appeal to them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. And it helps you identify red herrings-things that cost you little but might appeal to them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Running the pre-meeting questions and scenarios is especially important so you can identify red herrings to offer (issues that have no value for you but might have value for the other side) and build your defense line and your breaking point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So setting a clear agenda from the start matters too, I assume?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So setting a clear agenda from the start matters too, I assume?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Huge. Mutually agreeing on steps and outcomes upfront keeps things focused, even with all the variables like team size or location.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huge. Mutually agreeing on steps and outcomes upfront keeps things focused, even with all the variables like team size or location.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, all textbook examples of successful negotiations suggest that it is crucial to set up a clear and mutually agreed agenda right at the beginning, with a sequence of negotiation steps, and to clarify expected outcomes (e.g., signing a deal).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the psychological side? Negotiation's not just logic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the psychological side? Negotiation's not just logic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, showing respect and cool-headedness impacts outcomes more than people admit. It's about balancing confidence with professionalism.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, showing respect and cool-headedness impacts outcomes more than people admit. It's about balancing confidence with professionalism.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The psychological dimension of negotiation meetings makes a surprisingly big impact on the negotiation process and outcomes, even though in the business setting we expect to see extremely rational people with rational approaches. Therefore, successful negotiation includes showing your cool-headed professionalism, developing well-structured communication procedures and engaging in the bargaining process with full confidence as well as full respect for the person or a team across the table.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So in the end, it's about building your own style through experience.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So in the end, it's about building your own style through experience.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—keeping notes, learning from each deal. Whether you're a student or a pro, that personal archive is gold.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-keeping notes, learning from each deal. Whether you're a student or a pro, that personal archive is gold.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It doesnt matter if youre a professional negotiator, entrepreneur, business salesperson or just a graduate student, it is important to establish your own style and approach to the negotiation process by creating your personal archive with a set of notes or databank about every successful negotiation.
